review: This device is incompatible with the 5 Ghz band of the ASUS Dual Band RT-N56U router, despite Google's listing of this router as compatible.  They conveniently fail to mention some details.  The standard advice available from Google and other Internet comments (Disable AP [or Client] Isolation, Enable UPNP, and other more esoteric router settings) did not solve the problem.  While it is true this router will connect at the slower 2.4 GHz band, using that band requires the device controlling the Chromecast to also be set to this slower speed.  I choose to not set my brand new Galaxy 10.1 2014 to this slower speed just so I can use this Google device, so, for me, it's unusable.  Next stop, Roku 3.
author: Ron

review: This is a case where the product comes no where close to the hype. If you want to see your Chrome browser on your TV screen - then this is the product for you - though you then have to get really close to the TV screen to read much. If you want to display you PC pictures and other content on your TV and not through your browser - then you may want to reconsider. It is possible to display your screen on the TV using this application but it is less obvious (you click a pull down in the Chromecast icon in your browser but there isn't any real instructions on that) . Also it is all in beta.The net is that it does work - just not as well as you'd think and only if you have the Chrome browser.
